message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Toward Autonomous Multi-UAV Wireless Network: A Survey of Reinforcement Learning-Based Approaches
Paper Abstract: Publisher Copyright: Author
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here's a comprehensive overview of reinforcement learning based on the search results:

## Definition and Core Concept

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

## How It Works

Unlike supervised learning and unsupervised learning which discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data respectively, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)To learn to maximize rewards, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge to take the best action (exploitation).

## Key Applications

Reinforcement learning has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.

## Advanced Areas

**Deep Reinforcement Learning**: Deep reinforcement learning combines reinforcement learning and deep learning, allowing agents to make decisions from unstructured input data without manual engineering of the state space.

**Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning**: Multi-agent reinforcement learning is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

**Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback**: Reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) is a technique to align an intelligent agent with human preferences by training a reward model that can then be used to train other models through reinforcement learning.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Self-play (reinforcement learning technique) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-play_(reinforcement_learning_technique)"},{"title":"Model-free (reinforcement learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-free_(reinforcement_learning)"},{"title":"Category:Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"Self-supervised learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-supervised_learning"},{"title":"Imitation learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imitation_learning"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of reinforcement learning based on the search results:

## Definition and Core Concept

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

## How It Works

Unlike supervised learning and unsupervised learning which discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data respectively, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)To learn to maximize rewards, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge to take the best action (exploitation).

## Key Applications

Reinforcement learning has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.

## Advanced Areas

**Deep Reinforcement Learning**: Deep reinforcement learning combines reinforcement learning and deep learning, allowing agents to make decisions from unstructured input data without manual engineering of the state space.

**Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning**: Multi-agent reinforcement learning is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

**Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback**: Reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) is a technique to align an intelligent agent with human preferences by training a reward model that can then be used to train other models through reinforcement learning.

Web search results for query: "Autonomous system"

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous system (Internet) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system_(Internet)"},{"title":"Autonomous system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system"},{"title":"Autonomous system (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Non-autonomous system (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-autonomous_system_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Autonomous decentralized system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_decentralized_system"},{"title":"Low Cost Autonomous Attack System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Low_Cost_Autonomous_Attack_System"},{"title":"Autonomous Rotorcraft Sniper System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Rotorcraft_Sniper_System"},{"title":"Automated emergency braking system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_emergency_braking_system"},{"title":"Advanced driver-assistance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_driver-assistance_system"},{"title":"Navigation system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navigation_system"}]

Based on the search results, "Autonomous system" can refer to several different concepts depending on the context:

## Internet/Networking Context

An autonomous system (AS) is a collection of connected Internet Protocol (IP) routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operators on behalf of a single administrative entity or domain, that presents a common and clearly defined routing policy to the Internet.(no content)As of 2025, there are roughly 120,000 allocated ASNs.(no content)Autonomous systems can be grouped into four categories: multihomed (an AS that maintains connections to more than one other AS), stub (an AS that is connected to only one other AS), transit (an AS that acts as a router between two ASes), and internet exchange point.

## Mathematics Context

In mathematics, an autonomous system or autonomous differential equation is a system of ordinary differential equations which does not explicitly depend on the independent variable.(no content)When the variable is time, they are also called time-invariant systems.

## Other Definitions

There are also related concepts like autonomous decentralized systems (ADS), which are decentralized systems composed of modules or components that are designed to operate independently but are capable of interacting with each other to meet the overall goal of the system.

The term "autonomous system" can also refer to autonomous robots and other self-operating technologies depending on context.

I've performed a web search for "Unmanned aerial vehicle" and found comprehensive information about UAVs. Here's what I found:

## Definition

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with Austrian forces besieging Venice attempting to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)Significant development of drones started in the 1900s, and originally focused on providing practice targets for training military personnel.

## Commercial Development

In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.(no content)In 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone at $629, and the DJI Phantom was considered one of the most influential consumer drone products ever made.

## Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications, with a commercial drone market report identifying "237 ways that drones revolutionize business" throughout 15 industries including agriculture, energy, construction, and mining.

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Talk:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about multi-agent systems:

## Definition and Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in multi-agent systems are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous, with no agent designated as controlling (or the system is effectively reduced to a monolithic system).(no content)When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to common improvement, using languages such as Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Modern Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Relationship to Agent-Based Models

A multi-agent system is not always the same as an agent-based model (ABM), where the goal of an ABM is to search for explanatory insight into the collective behavior of agents obeying simple rules, typically in natural systems, rather than in solving specific practical or engineering problems.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about multi-agent systems:

## Definition and Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in multi-agent systems are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous, with no agent designated as controlling (or the system is effectively reduced to a monolithic system).(no content)When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to common improvement, using languages such as Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Modern Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Relationship to Agent-Based Models

A multi-agent system is not always the same as an agent-based model (ABM), where the goal of an ABM is to search for explanatory insight into the collective behavior of agents obeying simple rules, typically in natural systems, rather than in solving specific practical or engineering problems.

Links: [{"title":"Wireless network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_network"},{"title":"Wi-Fi - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wi-Fi"},{"title":"List of wireless network protocols - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_wireless_network_protocols"},{"title":"Wireless LAN - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_LAN"},{"title":"Wireless network interface controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_network_interface_controller"},{"title":"List of wireless network technologies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_wireless_network_technologies"},{"title":"Wireless broadband - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_broadband"},{"title":"Wireless ad hoc network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_ad_hoc_network"},{"title":"Wireless - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless"},{"title":"Wireless sensor network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_sensor_network"}]

## Wireless Network Overview

A wireless network is a computer network that uses wireless data connections between network nodes.(no content)Wireless networking allows homes, telecommunications networks, and business installations to avoid the costly process of introducing cables into a building, or as a connection between various locations.

### Key Types of Wireless Networks

**Wi-Fi (WLAN):** Wi-Fi is a family of wireless network protocols based on the IEEE 802.11 family of standards, which are commonly used for local area networking of devices and Internet access, allowing nearby digital devices to exchange data by radio waves.(no content)These are the most widely used computer networks, used globally in home and small office networks to link devices and to provide Internet access with wireless routers and wireless access points in public places such as coffee shops, restaurants, hotels, libraries, and airports.

**Wireless Personal Area Networks (WPANs):** Wireless personal area networks (WPANs) connect devices within a relatively small area, that is generally within a person's reach. For example, both Bluetooth radio and invisible infrared light provides a WPAN for interconnecting a headset to a laptop.

**Ad Hoc Networks:** A wireless ad hoc network, also known as a wireless mesh network or mobile ad hoc network (MANET), is a wireless network made up of radio nodes organized in a mesh topology. Each node forwards messages on behalf of the other nodes and each node performs routing.

**Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs):** Wireless sensor networks (WSNs) refer to networks of spatially dispersed and dedicated sensors that monitor and record the physical conditions of the environment and forward the collected data to a central location.

### Technology and Standards

Wi-Fi most commonly uses the 2.4 gigahertz (120 mm) UHF and 5 gigahertz (60 mm) SHF radio bands, with the 6 gigahertz SHF band used in newer generations of the standard; these bands are subdivided into multiple channels.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Summary

I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Toward Autonomous Multi-UAV Wireless Network: A Survey of Reinforcement Learning-Based Approaches". Here are the results:

**Paper Classification:** Survey (literature review of reinforcement learning approaches)

**Extracted Triples (5 total):**

1. **Reinforcement learning** (method) - Uses
   - The core technique surveyed for autonomous UAV control

2. **Unmanned aerial vehicle** (tool) - Uses
   - The primary systems being coordinated and studied

3. **Wireless network** (task) - Uses
   - The problem domain for multi-UAV communication

4. **Multi-agent system** (concept) - Uses
   - The framework for coordinating multiple autonomous agents

5. **Autonomous system** (concept) - Uses
   - The desired operational mode for UAV networks

All triples have been validated with proper Wikipedia URLs and pass the validation requirements. The survey appropriately builds on existing work (all "uses" relations) with 5 triples covering the essential technologies and concepts in the paper's scope.

Sources:
- [Reinforcement learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning)
- [Unmanned aerial vehicle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle)
- [Wireless network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_network)
- [Multi-agent system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system)
- [Autonomous system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system)
